message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest allergic rhinitis and among the options, intranasal corticosteroids are the most effective treatment for allergic rhinitis. Intranasal antihistamines are second line, while intranasal cromolyn sodium and decongestants are not first-line treatments for allergic rhinitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest allergic rhinitis and intranasal corticosteroids are the most effective option for managing this condition. Intranasal antihistamines and cromolyn sodium can also be effective but are not considered first-line treatment. Intranasal decongestants are not recommended for long-term use as they can cause rebound congestion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, intranasal corticosteroids are the most effective for allergic rhinitis symptoms and are generally well-tolerated. Intranasal antihistamines and cromolyn sodium are also options, but intranasal decongestants are not recommended for long-term use due to the risk of rebound congestion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Intranasal corticosteroids are the most effective treatment for allergic rhinitis and are recommended as the first-line treatment. Intranasal antihistamines are less effective and intranasal decongestants should be used for short-term relief only. Intranasal cromolyn sodium is an alternative treatment with less efficacy.

Intranasal antihistamines and cromolyn sodium are alternative options, but not the most appropriate next step. Intranasal decongestants should not be used long-term and can cause rebound congestion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Intranasal corticosteroids are the most effective medication for managing allergic rhinitis, especially for persistent symptoms like the patient’s. Intranasal antihistamines and cromolyn sodium are also effective but usually reserved for milder forms of allergic rhinitis. Intranasal decongestants should be avoided due to the risk of rebound congestion.

The patient's symptoms suggest allergic rhinitis, and intranasal corticosteroids are the most effective first-line treatment for allergic rhinitis. Intranasal antihistamines and cromolyn sodium may also be used, but they are not as effective as corticosteroids. Intranasal decongestants should be used with caution due to the risk of rebound congestion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Intranasal corticosteroids are the most effective and first-line treatment for allergic rhinitis, as they reduce inflammation and relieve all symptoms of allergic rhinitis. Intranasal antihistamines and decongestants are less effective and have more side effects. Intranasal cromolyn sodium is not as effective as corticosteroids and requires frequent administration.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. For management of allergic rhinitis, intranasal corticosteroids are the most effective and preferred initial treatment option. Intranasal antihistamines can also be used, but they are not as effective as corticosteroids. Intranasal decongestants should only be used for short-term relief of nasal congestion, and intranasal cromolyn sodium is not as effective as corticosteroids for symptom relief.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, intranasal corticosteroids are the most effective and recommended first-line treatment for allergic rhinitis. Intranasal antihistamines and cromolyn sodium can also be used as alternative therapies, but they are less effective. Intranasal decongestants should be avoided in patients with allergic rhinitis, as they can cause rebound congestion and worsen symptoms.
